intro: Ferula kaschkarovii, commonly known as the Karakorum ferula, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a perennial herb that typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, often at high altitudes. The plant is characterized by its tall, hollow stems and large, compound leaves that are adapted to withstand harsh climatic conditions. Its flowers are yellow and clustered in umbels, typical of the carrot family. Ferula kaschkarovii is also known for its aromatic resin, which has been used in traditional medicine and as a source of essential oils.
